newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RUGBY UNION-INJURIES FORCE FRANCE INTO LATE CHANGES.
newsitem.headline: RUGBY UNION-INJURIES FORCE FRANCE INTO LATE CHANGES.

text.p: France were forced to shuffle their back line on Friday after injuries ruled out centre Christophe Lamaison and fly-half Alain Penaud for Saturday's first rugby union test against Australia.
Richard Dourthe was named in midfield while David Aucagne will take the number 10 jersey for the clash at the Sydney Football Stadium.
Tricolores coach Jean-Claude Skrela made six changes from the side that clinched a memorable Five Nations grand slam triumph with victory over Scotland in Paris in March.
"Lamaison and Penaud would have played (against Australia) but the other players will do whatever they can to make sure their absence makes no difference," Skrela told reporters.
Dourthe, who will assume goal-kicking duties in Lamaison's absence, was named alongside Thomas Castaignede in the centres.
Lamaison, the hero of France's crucial Five Nations victory over England at Twickenham, was sidelined with a groin injury, while Penaud hurt his shoulder in training earlier this week.
Lock Olivier Brouzet forced his way into the side on the strength of a stirring performance in the tour win against Queensland on Tuesday, ousting Hugues Miorin in the process.
In a change to the front row, Christian Califano, who missed the victory over Scotland at Parc des Princes because of suspension, returned at prop in place of Didier Casadei.
Winger Philippe Bernat-Salles was also recalled, while Philippe Carbonneau was given the scrum-half job ahead of Guy Accoceberry.
"Lamaison and Penaud are not available so we will rely on other players. There is no point complaining about injuries because they are part of modern rugby," Skrela said.
France have beaten Queensland and ACT, who both fielded weakened sides, and an amateur Victoria team in their three tour matches since arriving in Australia 11 days ago.
Skrela said the preparations for a two-test series against the Wallabies had been far from ideal.
"But these days you have to adapt to short tours and be ready for the intensity of a test match," he said.
Both Queensland and ACT were without their test players after Wallaby coach Greg Smith called his squad together last week.
"We have had some good passages of play in all three tour matches but now we have put it together for the whole of a test match," Skrela said.
Australia, who named their test line-up on June 8, drafted ACT Brumbies fullback Stephen Larkham into the side three days later after Matt Burke succumbed to a niggling groin injury.
Australia and France will meet again in the second test at Ballymore in Brisbane on June 28.
Teams:

France - 15-Jean-Luc Sadourny; 14-Philippe Bernat-Salles, 13-Richard Dourthe, 12-Thomas Castaignede, 11-David Venditti; 10-David Aucagne, 9-Philippe Carbonneau; 8-Fabien Pelous, 7-Olivier Magne, 6-Abdel Benazzi (captain), 5-Olivier Merle, 4-Olivier Brouzet, 3-Christian Califano, 2-Marc Dal Maso, 1-Franck Tournaire.

Australia - 15-Stephen Larkham, 14-Ben Tune, 13-Jason Little, 12-Pat Howard, 11-Joe Roff; 10-Tim Horan, 9-George Gregan; 8-Daniel Manu, 7-David Wilson, 6-Brett Robinson, 5-John Eales (captain), 4-David Giffen, 3-Ewen McKenzie, 2-Marco Caputo, 1-Richard Harry.
